questions.text:
A 12-year-old boy comes to the physician for the evaluation of intermittent blood-tinged urine for several months. Four months ago, he had an episode of fever and sore throat that resolved without treatment after 5 days. During the past 2 years, he has also had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His brother died of a progressive kidney disease at the age of 23. The patient appears pale. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 70/min, and blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Slit lamp examination shows a conical protrusion of both lenses. Laboratory studies show:


Hemoglobin
11 g/dL


Serum



 Urea nitrogen
40 mg/dL


 Creatinine
2.4 mg/dL


Urine



 Blood

2+


 Protein

1+


 RBC
5–7/hpf


 RBC casts
rare


Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may manifest with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness and lenticonus seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Type II hypersensitivity reactions caused by antibodies against intrinsic type IV collagen antigens in the basement membrane are responsible for Goodpasture disease, which manifests with acute nephritic syndrome. However, Goodpasture disease rarely manifests during early childhood and usually progresses rapidly (unlike in this patient, who presents with a 2-year history of intermittent edema). Also, especially in younger individuals, pulmonary symptoms (e.g., hemoptysis, dyspnea) often precede the onset of nephritic syndrome.

C) INCORRECT:

A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of nephroblastoma (i.e., Wilms tumor), which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, nephroblastoma typically manifests in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination.

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy. Membranous nephropathy typically manifests between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 12-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome.

E) CORRECT:

Alport syndrome is caused by a genetic defect of type IV collagen, which is most commonly inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern. Type IV collagen is found in the glomerular basement membrane, the cochlea, and the lens of the eye. Thus, a defect of type IV collagen may result in hematuria and nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus leading to vision problems (patients with Alport syndrome “can't pee, can't see, can't hear a bee”).

The diagnosis of Alport syndrome is confirmed via skin biopsy (showing the absence of type IV collagen alpha-5 chains in the basement membrane) or, if skin biopsy is inconclusive, kidney biopsy. Patients with proteinuria, such as this boy, should receive ACE inhibitors or angiotensin II receptor blockers to slow the progression to end-stage renal disease.

F) INCORRECT:

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient had an episode of febrile pharyngitis 4 months ago that could be due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness and lenticonus in this patient.

G) INCORRECT:

Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 12-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy as well a family history of early death due to end-stage renal disease might suggest a diagnosis of autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which is a cause for multiple bilateral kidney cysts. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness and lenticonus. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

In about 15% of cases, Alport syndrome may be the result of an autosomal-recessive mutation. However, the majority of affected patients have an X-linked mutation.
questions.hint: This patient's recurrent edema of the face and feet, hypertension, elevated urea nitrogen and creatinine, and urinalysis that shows microscopic hematuria and proteinuria are suggestive of nephritic syndrome. The combination of intermittent gross hematuria, nephritic syndrome, sensorineural hearing loss, and anterior lenticonus in a patient with a family history of renal disease is indicative of Alport syndrome.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy comes to the physician because of a 4-month history of intermittent red urine. During the past 2 years, he has had recurrent episodes of swelling of his face and feet. Five years ago, he was diagnosed with mild bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. His uncle died of kidney disease in his twenties. His blood pressure is 145/85 mm Hg. Laboratory studies show a hemoglobin concentration of 12.5 g/dL, urea nitrogen concentration of 40 mg/dL, and creatinine concentration of 2.4 mg/dL. Urinalysis shows 5–7 RBC/hpf. Which of the following is the most likely underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Type IV collagen, which forms a component of basement membranes, plays an important role in the function of glomeruli and inner ear structures (particularly the organ of Corti). An X-linked defect in type IV collagen is responsible for most cases of Alport's syndrome, which results in progressive sensorineural hearing loss (with high-frequency sounds affected first) and hematuria. Episodes of gross hematuria are sometimes preceded by upper respiratory tract infections. Patients with Alport's syndrome also commonly develop an anterior lenticonus since type IV collagen is the predominant collagen fiber in the lens capsule. A family history of renal disease among males is common in patients with Alport's syndrome.
Image Description:

Electron micrograph of a kidney biopsy sample.

The glomerular basement membrane (GBM) demonstrates an irregular thickness, with splitting and a basket-weave appearance (black arrow).

These findings are consistent with Alport syndrome.

B) INCORRECT:

A WT1 gene mutation is one of the causes of Wilms tumor, which can result in hematuria, hypertension, and anemia. However, Wilms tumor would manifest in early childhood (usually before the age of 5 years) and patients almost always have a palpable abdominal or flank mass on physical examination. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

C) INCORRECT:

An autosomal-recessive gene defect in fibrocystin is the cause of autosomal-recessive polycystic kidney disease (ARPKD), which leads to the development of multiple bilateral kidney cysts. Hematuria, hypertension, anemia, and raised creatinine in a 10-year-old child with an onset of symptoms during infancy and a positive family history might suggest a diagnosis of ARPKD. However, ARPKD does not account for sensorineural deafness. Instead, patients with ARPKD who survive to adolescence usually have evidence of cirrhosis and portal hypertension (e.g., ascites, splenomegaly).

D) INCORRECT:

Antibodies against phospholipase A2 receptors on podocytes are responsible for membranous nephropathy, which typically presents between the ages of 30 and 50 years with nephrotic syndrome, unlike this 10-year-old boy child with nephritic syndrome. It also does not cause sensorineural hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Pharyngitis caused by group A beta-hemolytic streptococci (GAS) is common in children 5–15 years of age and can cause poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN) 1–3 weeks after the infection. This patient could have had an episode of febrile pharyngitis due to GAS. However, while PSGN would present with nephritic syndrome, it does not explain the 2-year history of intermittent edema or the presence of sensorineural deafness in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Deposition of IgA in the glomeruli is seen in IgA nephropathy and in Henoch-Schönlein purpura (HSP), both of which may present with nephritic syndrome. However, a purpuric rash would typically precede the onset of renal disease in patients with HSP, and other symptoms such as abdominal pain and/or joint pain would be expected. Moreover, both HSP and IgA nephropathy do not explain the sensorineural deafness in this patient.
questions.hint: This patient presents with features of nephritic syndrome, including hematuria, hypertension, and recurrent edema of the face and feet, and other signs of renal damage (elevated BUN, elevated creatinine). Sensorineural hearing loss in a patient with renal disease and a positive family history is indicative of Alport syndrome.

questions.text:
A 15-year-old boy presents for evaluation of hematuria and proteinuria. He is otherwise healthy and takes no medications. His family history is notable for a maternal uncle with end-stage kidney disease and deafness. The family has declined genetic testing.
The patient's vital signs, including blood pressure, are normal for his age, and his physical examination is unremarkable. Laboratory testing reveals a blood urea nitrogen level of 18 mg/dL (reference range, 5–18) and a serum creatinine level of 1.0 mg/dL (0.5–1.0).
Urinalysis demonstrates 3+ protein in a sample with a specific gravity of 1.015 (1.00–1.035). Urine microscopy confirms numerous red cells but is otherwise normal.
An ultrasound shows no mass or other structural abnormality.
A decision is made to proceed to renal biopsy. What is the most likely finding on biopsy?

choices.text: Immature glomeruli with undifferentiated collecting ducts on light microscopy
Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis on light microscopy
Irregular basement membrane with thick and abnormally thin segments
Accumulation of material in lysosomes on electron microscopy
Mesangial staining of immunoglobulin A on immunofluorescence

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Immature glomeruli with undifferentiated collecting ducts would be seen in a dysplastic kidney but would be identified on ultrasound. This patient’s ultrasound was normal.

B) INCORRECT:

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can be primary (with diffuse podocyte injury) or secondary (related to a previous renal insult and reduced nephron number). Proteinuria, often leading to nephrotic syndrome, is the primary feature of FSGS. Hematuria is not typically seen with this disorder, although it can be present.

C) CORRECT:

This patient’s hematuria in the context of a family history of deafness and end-stage kidney disease is concerning for Alport syndrome, a hereditary nephritis caused by mutations in the genes encoding type IV collagen (a component of Bowman capsule, mesangial matrix, and glomerular basement membrane).

Most cases of Alport syndrome (85%) are inherited through X-linked transmission of mutations in the COL4A5 gene. Hematuria is often the initial manifestation, with proteinuria and hypertension occurring by late childhood or early adolescence, followed by a decline in renal function. The majority of males with X-linked Alport syndrome develop end-stage kidney disease by 30 years of age, and all have it by age 60. Bilateral sensorineural hearing loss is also common in Alport syndrome, affecting around 80% of males with X-linked inheritance; the loss is not usually detectable until late childhood and then progresses at a rate similar to that of the patient’s renal insufficiency. Ocular abnormalities, including defects in the lens, retina, and cornea, are also common.

When Alport syndrome is suspected on the basis of family history, the diagnosis can be confirmed by genetic testing or by skin or renal biopsy with staining for type IV collagen. Renal biopsy will initially demonstrate diffuse attenuation of the glomerular basement membrane (GBM) with ultimate progression to the pathognomonic lesions of Alport syndrome: splitting of the lamina densa into multiple strands and scalloping of the epithelial aspect of the GBM. This will be seen on biopsy as an irregular basement membrane with thick and abnormally thin segments. Immunofluorescence staining for type IV collagen aids in diagnosis if it demonstrates a lack of type IV collagen in the basement membrane.

For patients with Alport syndrome, conservative treatment of hypertension and proteinuria with agents that block the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system may slow progression to ESRD. For those who develop ESRD, renal transplantation outcomes are typically excellent.

Key learning point: Hematuria and proteinuria in a child with a family history of deafness and end-stage kidney disease should raise suspicion for Alport syndrome.

D) INCORRECT:

Accumulation of material in lysosomes on electron microscopy can be seen in patients with Fabry disease, an X-linked recessive lysosomal storage disease caused by deficient activity of alpha-galactosidase A. Symptoms typically begin in the second or third decade of life with development of angiokeratoma (usually in a bathing-trunk distribution), acroparesthesia, and anhidrosis. Proteinuria rather than hematuria is the major renal manifestation.

E) INCORRECT:

Mesangial staining of immunoglobulin A (IgA) on immunofluorescence is seen in IgA nephropathy. Hearing loss does not develop in patients with IgA nephropathy.
